commit_message:
Fixed wording and reorganised Block Storage intro

As per the bug, updated the wording and slightly reorganised
the Block Storage intro. Watch this space for the rest of the book.

Change-Id: I38d1a6c0c9dc093235db0573399fab459a5bc1db
backport: havana
Partial-Bug: #1251195
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/09/57109/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para> OpenStack Block Storage allows you to add block-level storage to your OpenStack Compute instances. It is similar in function to the Amazon EC2 Elastic Block Storage (EBS) offering. </para> <para> The OpenStack Block Storage service uses a series of daemon processes. Each process will have the prefix <systemitem class="service">cinder-</systemitem>, and they will all run persistently on the host. The binaries can all be run on from a single node, or they can be spread across multiple nodes. They can also be run on the same node as other OpenStack services. </para> <para> The default OpenStack Block Storage service implementation is an iSCSI solution that uses Logical Volume Manager (LVM) for Linux. It also provides drivers that allow you to use a back-end storage device from a different vendor, in addition to or instead of the base LVM implementation. </para> <para> The OpenStack Block Storage service is not a shared storage solution like a Storage Area Network (SAN) of NFS volumes, where you can attach a volume to multiple servers. With the OpenStack Block Storage service, you can attach a volume to only one instance at a time. </para> <para> This chapter uses a simple example to demonstrate Block Storage. In this example, one cloud controller runs the <systemitem class="service">nova-api</systemitem>, <literal>nova-network</literal> and <literal>cinder-*</literal> services. There are two additional compute nodes running <systemitem class="service">nova-compute</systemitem>. </para> The example in this chapter uses a custom partitioning scheme that uses 60GB of space and labels it as a Logical Volume (LV). The network uses <literal>FlatManager</literal> as the <literal>NetworkManager</literal> setting for OpenStack Compute. </para> <para> The network mode does not interfere with the way Block Storage works, but networking must be set up. For more information on networking, see <xref linkend="ch_networking"/>. <section xml:id="section_manage-volumes"> <title>Manage volumes</title> <para> To set up Compute to use volumes, you must have <systemitem class="service">lvm2</systemitem> installed. </para> <para> This procedure creates and attaches a volume to a server instance. </para> <procedure> <step> <para> The <command>cinder create</command> command creates a logical volume (LV) in the volume group (VG) <parameter>cinder-volumes</parameter>. </para> <para> Create a volume: </para> <programlisting>$ cinder create</programlisting> </step> <step> <para> The <command>nova volume-attach</command> command creates a unique iSCSI IQN that is exposed to the compute node. </para> <para> Attach the LV to an instance: </para> <programlisting>$ nova volume-attach</programlisting> </step> <step> <para> The OpenStack Block Storage service and OpenStack Compute can now be configured using the <filename>cinder.conf</filename> configuration file. </para> </step> </procedure> <para> The compute node, which runs the instance, now has an active iSCSI session. It will also have a new local disk, usually a <filename>/dev/sdX</filename> disk. This local storage is used by libvirt as storage for the instance. The instance itself will usually get a separate new disk, usually a <filename>/dev/vdX</filename> disk. </para> <para> In some cases, instances can be stored and run from within volumes. For more information, see the <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/boot_from_volume.html"> Launch an instance from a volume</link> section in the <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/"> <citetitle>OpenStack End User Guide</citetitle></link>. </para> <title>Troubleshoot your installation</title> <para> This section contains troubleshooting information for Block Storage. </para>
deleted_lines: <para>The OpenStack Block Storage service works though the interaction of a series of daemon processes named cinder-* that reside persistently on the host machine or machines. The binaries can all be run from a single node, or spread across multiple nodes. They can also be run on the same node as other OpenStack services.</para> <section xml:id="section_block-storage-intro"> <title>Introduction to Block Storage</title> <para>To administer the OpenStack Block Storage service, it is helpful to understand a number of concepts. You must make certain choices when you configure the Block Storage service in OpenStack. The bulk of the options come down to two choices, single node or multi-node install. You can read a longer discussion about storage decisions in <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/openstack-ops/content/storage_decision.html" >Storage Decisions</link> in the <citetitle>OpenStack Operations Guide</citetitle>.</para> <para>The OpenStack Block Storage service enables you to add extra block-level storage to your OpenStack Compute instances. This service is similar to the Amazon EC2 Elastic Block Storage (EBS) offering.</para> </section> <?hard-pagebreak?> <section xml:id="section_manage-volumes"> <title>Manage volumes</title> <para>The default OpenStack Block Storage service implementation is an iSCSI solution that uses Logical Volume Manager (LVM) for Linux.</para> <para>The OpenStack Block Storage service is not a shared storage solution like a Storage Area Network (SAN) of NFS volumes, where you can attach a volume to multiple servers. With the OpenStack Block Storage service, you can attach a volume to only one instance at a time.</para> <para>The OpenStack Block Storage service also provides drivers that enable you to use several vendors' back-end storage devices, in addition to or instead of the base LVM implementation.</para> <para>The following high-level procedure shows you how to create and attach a volume to a server instance.</para> <procedure> <step><para>You must configure both OpenStack Compute and the OpenStack Block Storage service through the <filename>cinder.conf</filename> file.</para></step> <step> <para>Create a volume through the <command>cinder create</command> command. This command creates an LV into the volume group (VG) "cinder-volumes." </para> </step> <step> <para>Attach the volume to an instance through the <command>nova volume-attach</command> command. This command creates a unique iSCSI IQN that is exposed to the compute node.</para> <substeps> <step> <para>The compute node, which runs the instance, now has an active ISCSI session and new local storage (usually a /dev/sdX disk).</para> </step> <step> <para>libvirt uses that local storage as storage for the instance. The instance get a new disk, usually a /dev/vdX disk.</para> </step> </substeps> </step> </procedure> <para>For this particular walk through, there is one cloud controller running <systemitem class="service">nova-api</systemitem>, <literal>nova-network</literal> and <literal>cinder-*</literal> services. There are two additional compute nodes running <systemitem class="service">nova-compute</systemitem>. The walk through uses a custom partitioning scheme that carves out 60GB of space and labels it as LVM. The network uses <literal>FlatManager</literal> is the <literal>NetworkManager</literal> setting for OpenStack Compute (Nova).</para> <para>The network mode does not interfere with the way cinder works, but networking must be set up for cinder to work. For details, see <xref linkend="ch_networking"/>.</para> <para>To set up Compute to use volumes, ensure that Block Storage is installed along with lvm2. This guide describes how to:</para> <itemizedlist> <listitem> <para>Troubleshoot your installation.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Back up your Compute volumes.</para> </listitem> </itemizedlist> <section xml:id="boot-from-volume"> <title>Boot from volume</title> <para>In some cases, instances can be stored and run from inside volumes. For information, see the <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/boot_from_volume.html" >Launch an instance from a volume</link> section in the <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/"><citetitle>OpenStack End User Guide</citetitle></link>.</para> </section> <?hard-pagebreak?> <title>Troubleshooting your installation</title> <para>This section contains a few useful tips for troubleshooting your Block Storage installation.</para>

subject: Set LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI in .bashrc
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-21 18:15:50.000000000', 'files': ['scripts/devtest.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator/commit/cdcbf0d6ad664203ba20bf228758bb142d5017b0', 'message': 'Set LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI in .bashrc

If LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI is not set on login then the virtual power
manager may not be able to find the instances it is supposed to
manage.

Change-Id: I39540f785f5cb89879e25cc5928d9a580c69dc7b
'}]
commit_message:
Set LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI in .bashrc

If LIBVIRT_DEFAULT_URI is not set on login then the virtual power
manager may not be able to find the instances it is supposed to
manage.

Change-Id: I39540f785f5cb89879e25cc5928d9a580c69dc7b

commit_message:
Relocates app.install_if_needed()

Need to execute this method before configuring the guest.

Fixes: bug #1251689

Change-Id: I3cce6b35fc40f4ff4cc45b04714067956fb1869e

commit_message:
Add ML2 plugin support

This patch aims to support:
- ml2 configuration for Open-vSwitch & Linux Bridge plugins
- mechanism drivers: flat, gre, vlan vxlan
- l2 population support for OVS & linux bridge plugins

implement blueprint ml2-support
Change-Id: I9a4224f899e95411c509f583bf04dfc4dd0de25b
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/89/48289/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Copyright (C) 2013 eNovance SAS <licensing@enovance.com> # # Author: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # Configure the neutron server to use the ML2 plugin. # This configures the plugin for the API server, but does nothing # about configuring the agents that must also run and share a config # file with the OVS plugin if both are on the same machine. # # === Parameters # # [*type_drivers*] # (optional) List of network type driver entrypoints to be loaded # from the neutron.ml2.type_drivers namespace. # Could be an array that can have these elements: # local, flat, vlan, gre, vxlan # Defaults to ['local', 'flat', 'vlan', 'gre', 'vxlan']. # # [*tenant_network_types*] # (optional) Ordered list of network_types to allocate as tenant networks. # The value 'local' is only useful for single-box testing # but provides no connectivity between hosts. # Should be an array that can have these elements: # local, flat, vlan, gre, vxlan # Defaults to ['local', 'flat', 'vlan', 'gre', 'vxlan']. # # [*mechanism_drivers*] # (optional) An ordered list of networking mechanism driver # entrypoints to be loaded from the neutron.ml2.mechanism_drivers namespace. # Should be an array that can have these elements: # logger, test, linuxbridge, openvswitch, hyperv, ncs, arista, cisco_nexus, # l2 population. # Default to ['openvswitch', 'linuxbridge']. # # [*flat_networks*] # (optional) List of physical_network names with which flat networks # can be created. Use * to allow flat networks with arbitrary # physical_network names. # Should be an array. # Default to *. # # [*network_vlan_ranges*] # (optional) List of <physical_network>:<vlan_min>:<vlan_max> or # <physical_network> specifying physical_network names # usable for VLAN provider and tenant networks, as # well as ranges of VLAN tags on each available for # allocation to tenant networks. # Should be an array with vlan_min = 1 & vlan_max = 4094 (IEEE 802.1Q) # Default to empty. # # [*tunnel_id_ranges*] # (optional) Comma-separated list of <tun_min>:<tun_max> tuples # enumerating ranges of GRE tunnel IDs that are # available for tenant network allocation # Should be an array with tun_max +1 - tun_min > 1000000 # Default to empty. # # [*vxlan_group*] # (optional) Multicast group for VXLAN. # Multicast group for VXLAN. If unset, disables VXLAN enable sending allocate # broadcast traffic to this multicast group. When left unconfigured, will # disable multicast VXLAN mode # Should be an Multicast IP (v4 or v6) address. # Default to 'None'. # # [*vni_ranges*] # (optional) Comma-separated list of <vni_min>:<vni_max> tuples # enumerating ranges of VXLAN VNI IDs that are # available for tenant network allocation. # Min value is 0 and Max value is 16777215. # Default to empty. # class neutron::plugins::ml2 ( $type_drivers = ['local', 'flat', 'vlan', 'gre', 'vxlan'], $tenant_network_types = ['local', 'flat', 'vlan', 'gre', 'vxlan'], $mechanism_drivers = ['openvswitch', 'linuxbridge'], $flat_networks = ['*'], $network_vlan_ranges = [], $tunnel_id_ranges = [], $vxlan_group = false, $vni_ranges = [] ) { include neutron::params # test mechanism drivers if ! $mechanism_drivers { warning('Without networking mechanism driver, ml2 will not communicate with L2 agents') } # test tunnel id range define test_tunnel_id_range { $first_id = regsubst($name,'^(\d+)\:(\d+)$','\1') $second_id = regsubst($name,'^(\d+)\:(\d+)$','\1') if (($second_id - $first_id) > 1000000) { fail('tunnel id range is to large.') } if (($second_id - $first_id) < 0 ) { fail('tunnel id range is invalid.') } } # test network vlan range define test_network_vlan_range { $first_id = regsubst($name,'^(\d+)\:(\d+)$','\1') $second_id = regsubst($name,'^(\d+)\:(\d+)$','\1') if ($first_id > 4094) or ($second_id > 4094) { fail('vlan id is invalid.') } if (($second_id - $first_id) < 0 ) { fail('network vlan range is invalid.') } } # test vni range define test_vni_range { if (! $name =~ /^[0-16777215]\:[0-16777215]$/) { fail('vni range is invalid.') } } define configure_ml2_drivers { if ($name == 'flat') { neutron_plugin_ml2 { 'ml2_type_flat/flat_networks': value => join($flat_networks, ','); } } elsif ($name == 'gre') { # tunnel_id_ranges is required in gre if ! $tunnel_id_ranges { fail('when gre is part of type_drivers, tunnel_id_ranges should be given.') } test_tunnel_id_range { $tunnel_id_ranges:; } neutron_plugin_ml2 { 'ml2_type_gre/tunnel_id_ranges': value => join($tunnel_id_ranges, ','); } } elsif ($name == 'vlan') { # network_vlan_ranges is required in vlan if ! $network_vlan_ranges { fail('when vlan is part of type_drivers, network_vlan_ranges should be given.') } test_network_vlan_range { $network_vlan_ranges:; } neutron_plugin_ml2 { 'ml2_type_vlan/network_vlan_ranges': value => join($network_vlan_ranges, ','); } } elsif ($name == 'vxlan') { # vni_ranges and vxlan_group are required in vxlan if (! $vni_ranges) or (! $vxlan_group) { fail('when vxlan is part of type_drivers, vni_ranges and vxlan_group should be given.') } # test multicast ip address (ipv4 else ipv6): if $vxlan_group =~ /^2[\d.]+$/ { if (! $vxlan_group =~ /^(22[4-9]|23[0-9])\.(\d+)\.(\d+)\.(\d+)$/) { fail('multicast ipv4 address is not valid for vxlan_group.') } } elsif (! $vxlan_group =~ /^ff[\d.]+$/) { fail('multicast is not valid for vxlan_group.') } test_vni_range { $vni_ranges: } neutron_plugin_ml2 { 'ml2_type_vxlan/vxlan_group': value => $vxlan_group; 'ml2_type_vxlan/vni_ranges': value => join($vni_ranges, ','); } } elsif ($name == 'local') { warning('local type_driver is useful only for single-box, because it provides no connectivity between hosts') } else { # detect an invalid type_drivers value fail('type_driver unknown.') } } configure_ml2_drivers { $type_drivers: } # Configure ml2_conf.ini neutron_plugin_ml2 { 'ml2/type_drivers': value => join($type_drivers, ','); 'ml2/tenant_network_types': value => join($tenant_network_types, ','); 'ml2/mechanism_drivers': value => join($mechanism_drivers, ','); } # Ensure the neutron-common package is installed before config Package['neutron-common'] -> Neutron_plugin_ml2<||> if $::osfamily == 'Redhat' { file {'/etc/neutron/plugin.ini': ensure => link, target => '/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini', require => Package['openstack-neutron'] } } }

commit_message:
Support building wheels (PEP-427)

With that, "python setup.py bdist_wheel" could be used for building and uploading wheels to PyPI.

Change-Id: Idb063ef409c134738c437ce1c49fef82d0fbf923

commit_message:
Re-factor each resource implementation into separate file

We are adding code for different resources and v1.py is growing. It will
be better to have each resource implementation in a separate file.

Change-Id: Ibc1a3523ed4545c02b437540aec7b063b9e2c87f

commit_message:
Support building wheels (PEP-427)

commit_message:
Don't use deprecated module commands

The commands module was deprecated since version 2.6 and it has been
removed in Python 3. This patch uses processutils.trycmd method to
replace of deprecated module commands.
See http://docs.python.org/2/library/commands#module-commands

Closes-Bug: #1248216

Change-Id: Iee0b3cf59c738bfda9c5b2049a1853abbb6d16e0

commit_message:
Line wrap README, revise IRC channel to #openstack-barbican

Change-Id: Id7840adb5d8863e668d2ab23820fd1346c349f53
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/16/57716/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Barbican is a ReST API designed for the secure storage, provisioning and management of secrets. It is aimed at being useful for all environments, including large ephemeral Clouds. The project is supported by [Rackspace Hosting](http://www.rackspace.com). Barbican is part of a set of applications that make up the CloudKeep ecosystem. The other systems are: * [Postern](https://github.com/cloudkeep/postern) - Go based agent that provides access to secrets from the Barbican API. * [Palisade](https://github.com/cloudkeep/palisade) - AngularJS based web ui for the Barbican API. * [Python-barbicanclient](https://github.com/cloudkeep/python-barbicanclient) - A convenient Python-based library to interact with the Barbican API. Additional documentation can be found on the [Github Wiki](https://github.com/cloudkeep/barbican/wiki). For questions, comments or concerns, hop on the OpenStack dev mailing list at `openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org` and let us know what you think, just add `[barbican]` to the subject. You can also join our Freenode IRC at `#openstack-barbican`. To file a bug, use our bug tracker on [Launchpad](https://bugs.launchpad.net/barbican/).Please visit our [Getting Started wiki page ](https://github.com/cloudkeep/barbican/wiki/Barbican-Getting-Started-Guide) for details. The current state of key management is atrocious. While Windows does have some decent options through the use of the Data Protection API (DPAPI) and Active Directory, Linux lacks a cohesive story around how to manage keys for application use. Barbican was designed to solve this problem. The system was motivated by internal Rackspace needs, requirements from [OpenStack](http://www.openstack.org/) and a realization that the current state of the art could use some help.* **Symmetric Keys** - Used to perform reversible encryption of data at rest, typically using the AES algorithm set. This type of key is required to enable features like [encrypted Swift containers and Cinder volumes](http://www.openstack.org/software/openstack-storage/), [encrypted Cloud Backups](http://www.rackspace.com/cloud/backup/), etc. * **Asymmetric Keys** - Asymmetric key pairs (sometimes referred to as [public / private keys](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography)) are used in many scenarios where communication between untrusted parties is desired. The most common case is with SSL/TLS certificates, but also is used in solutions like SSH keys, S/MIME (mail) encryption and digital signatures. * **Raw Secrets** - Barbican stores secrets as a base64 encoded block of data (encrypted, naturally). Clients can use the API to store any secrets in any format they desire. The [Postern](https://github.com/cloudkeep/postern) agent is capable of presenting these secrets in various formats to ease integration. For the symmetric and asymmetric key types, Barbican supports full lifecycle management including provisioning, expiration, reporting, etc. A plugin system allows for multiple certificate authority support (including public and private CAs).1. Provide a central secret-store capable of distributing secret / keying material to all types of deployments including ephemeral Cloud instances.5. Improve security through sane defaults and centralized management of [policies for all secrets](https://github.com/cloudkeep/barbican/wiki/Policies).

Additional documentation can be found on the [Github Wiki](https://github.com/cloudkeep/barbican/wiki). For questions, comments or concerns, hop on the OpenStack dev mailing list at `openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org` and let us know what you think, just add `[barbican]` to the subject. You can also join our Freenode IRC at `#openstack-cloudkeep`. To file a bug, use our bug tracker on [Launchpad](https://bugs.launchpad.net/barbican/). * [Please visit our Getting Started wiki page for details](https://github.com/cloudkeep/barbican/wiki/Barbican-Getting-Started-Guide) The current state of key management is atrocious. Barbican was designed to solve this problem. The system was motivated by internal Rackspace needs, requirements from [OpenStack](http://www.openstack.org/) and a realization that the current state of the art could use some help.* **Symmetric Keys** - Used to perform reversible encryption of data at rest, typically using the AES algorithm set. This type of key is required to enable features like [encrypted Swift containers and Cinder volumes](http://www.openstack.org/software/openstack-storage/), [encrypted Cloud Backups](http://www.rackspace.com/cloud/backup/), etc. * **Asymmetric Keys** - Asymmetric key pairs (sometimes referred to as [public / private keys](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography)) are used in many scenarios where communication between untrusted parties is desired. The most common case is with SSL/TLS certificates, but also is used in solutions like SSH keys, S/MIME (mail) encryption and digital signatures. * **Raw Secrets** - Barbican stores secrets as a base64 encoded block of data (encrypted, naturally). Clients can use the API to store any secrets in any format they desire. The [Postern](https://github.com/cloudkeep/postern) agent is capable of presenting these secrets in various formats to ease integration. For the symmetric and asymmetric key types, Barbican supports full lifecycle management including provisioning, expiration, reporting, etc. A plugin system allows for multiple certificate authority support (including public and private CAs).1. Provide a central secret-store capable of distributing secret / keying material to all types of deployments including ephemeral Cloud instances.5. Improve security through sane defaults and centralized management of [policies for all secrets](https://github.com/cloudkeep/barbican/wiki/Policies).

commit_message:
Improve error reporting on import failures

The existing config generator code does not report general errors
importing modules well.  In my case, that meant I had no idea that
an old version of six on my system was causing a module import to
fail.

This change logs all errors importing a module to stderr.

Change-Id: I4663f5bbd4f553c0d6ce5f84b1c1275a7304e3b5

subject: Clean up extra modules code
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-20 17:06:08.000000000', 'files': ['openstack/common/config/generator.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/6cd1c3355bdc5721330f063797973cc8fad132f0', 'message': "Clean up extra modules code

The config generator extra modules code was attempting to look up
an empty module name if extra modules were not specified.  This
resulted in a spurious exception.

This change also strips the module names so extra spaces in the

Change-Id: I4cfbeb62fc25220ab43d6f80006245be3376dc93

commit_message:
Clean up extra modules code

The config generator extra modules code was attempting to look up
an empty module name if extra modules were not specified.  This
resulted in a spurious exception.

This change also strips the module names so extra spaces in the
env var won't cause problems.

Change-Id: I4cfbeb62fc25220ab43d6f80006245be3376dc93
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/98/57498/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: extra_modules = os.getenv("OSLO_CONFIG_GENERATOR_EXTRA_MODULES", "") if extra_modules: for module_name in extra_modules.split(','): module_name = module_name.strip() module = _import_module(module_name) if module: for group, opts in _list_opts(module): opts_by_group.setdefault(group, []).append((module_name, opts))
deleted_lines: for module_name in os.getenv( "OSLO_CONFIG_GENERATOR_EXTRA_MODULES", "").split(','): module = _import_module(module_name) if module: for group, opts in _list_opts(module): opts_by_group.setdefault(group, []).append((module_name, opts))

commit_message:
Refactor reset-db so we don't sync by default.

Now that we call db sync in post configure for each service
we no longer need to do it here.

Refactors the reset-db script so that we don't call DB sync's by
default. We still support the ability to db sync with reset-db
by passing in a single parameter.

commit_message:
Wait for nova to initialise

As the service dbsync's now happen in postconfigure.d nova is now
available some time after keystone. This commit adds a wait for the nova
api service in order to ensure we don't prematurely try to use nova.

This will be required once https://review.openstack.org/#/c/57466/ is
merged.

Change-Id: I6db65178b12df02b59c267b6d502c6bed1c6ac85
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/55/57655/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo "Waiting for nova to initialise..." wait_for 30 10 nova list

commit_message:
Fixes inconsistent usage of 'mount_point' in guestagent.

In trove.guestagent.datastore.mysql.manager.Manager#prepare
'mount_point' is taken from two different sources,
method parameter and CONF. It could cause issues when
parameter value differs from the one ftom CONF.
This patch fixes the issue.

It is suggested also to remove 'mount_point' parameter --
by a separate patch.

Fixes bug: 1248212

Change-Id: If8a93c475752d8cc3043883c73c1ae5ce4488701
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/81/56881/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use auth_url as mgmt_url if not admin identity

If admin identity endpoint is not found from the returned service catalog,
the given message error is Unable to authorize user by shell.py, when
httpclient.py raises an AuthorizationFailure exception with the message
Current authorization does not have a known management url but this one
is suppressed by the message previously mentioned in shell.py, in order
to solve this bug it is possible to use the auth_url as management_url

Change-Id: I17cab45a0193a80d555b3d37408dd439f70676eb
Closes-Bug: #120899
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/04/57704/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

""" uri = common_types.Uri "Uri to the sensor" name = wtypes.text "Name of the sensor" type = wtypes.text "Sensor type" description = wtypes.text "Description of the sensor" documentation = common_types.Uri "Documentation uri for the sensor" targetResource = common_types.Uri "Target resource uri to the sensor" sensorType = wtypes.text "Sensor type" value = sensorType "Value of sensor" timestamp = datetime.datetime "Timestamp for Sensor" operationsUri = common_types.Uri "Operations uri for the sensor" @classmethod def sample(cls): return cls(uri='http://localhost/v1/sensors/hb, name='hb, description='A heartbeat sensor', sensorLinks=[common_types.Link( href='http://localhost:9777/v1/sensors/s2', targetName='s2')]) class SensorController(rest.RestController): """Manages operations on a single sensor. """ def __init__(self, sensor_id): pecan.request.context['sensor_id'] = sensor_id self._id = sensor_id @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Sensor, wtypes.text) def get(self): """Return this sensor.""" error = _("Not implemented") pecan.response.translatable_error = error raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(unicode(error)) @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Sensor, wtypes.text, body=Sensor) def put(self, data): """Modify this sensor.""" error = _("Not implemented") pecan.response.translatable_error = error raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(unicode(error)) @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(None, wtypes.text, status_code=204) def delete(self): """Delete this sensor.""" error = _("Not implemented") pecan.response.translatable_error = error raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(unicode(error)) class Sensors(wtypes.Base): """A collection of sensors returned on listing. """ uri = common_types.Uri "Uri to the Sensors" name = wtypes.text "Name of the sensor" type = wtypes.text "Sensor type" description = wtypes.text "Description of the sensor" targetResource = common_types.Uri "Target resource uri to the sensor" sensorLinks = [common_types.Link] "List of links to the available sensors" @classmethod def sample(cls): return cls(uri='http://localhost/v1/sensors', sensorLinks=[common_types.Link( href='http://localhost:9777/v1/sensors/y4', targetName='y4')]) class SensorsController(rest.RestController): """Manages operations on the sensors collection.""" @pecan.expose() def _lookup(self, sensor_id, *remainder): if remainder and not remainder[-1]: remainder = remainder[:-1] return SensorController(sensor_id), remainder @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Sensor, body=Sensor, status_code=201) def post(self, data): """Create a new sensor.""" error = _("Not implemented") pecan.response.translatable_error = error raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(unicode(error)) @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Sensors) def get_all(self): """Return all sensors, based on the query provided.""" host_url = '/'.join([pecan.request.host_url, 'v1', 'sensors']) return Sensors(uri=host_url, type='sensors', description='Collection of sensors', sensorLinks=[]) sensors = SensorsController()

subject: Don't specify a default instance size, create tiny and micro
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-21 00:24:58.000000000', 'files': ['upgrade-tempest'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/grenade/commit/71b8ea61f05960c60feac076bfe216c80effb46c', 'message': "Don't specify a default instance size, create tiny and micro

In order to let grenade run tempest tests in parallel on virtual
environments we need to create the same tiny and micro guests that
we create in a normal devstack run. Otherwise we blow memory on
the environment, causing a scheduler fail, and sadness. Also no
cake.

Removing the explicit setting of DEFAULT_INSTANCE_TYPE will make
tempest create appropriate instance sizes, and use them in it's
guests.

Change-Id: I6adde22499853d0cde53771e83ebf5c5f7041c11
Partial-Bug: 1252170
"}]
commit_message:
Don't specify a default instance size, create tiny and micro

In order to let grenade run tempest tests in parallel on virtual
environments we need to create the same tiny and micro guests that
we create in a normal devstack run. Otherwise we blow memory on
the environment, causing a scheduler fail, and sadness. Also no
cake.

Removing the explicit setting of DEFAULT_INSTANCE_TYPE will make
tempest create appropriate instance sizes, and use them in it's
guests.

Change-Id: I6adde22499853d0cde53771e83ebf5c5f7041c11
Partial-Bug: 1252170

added_lines: operations = [common_types.Link] "List of links to operations" targetName='z4')], operations=[common_types.Link( href='http://localhost:9777/v1/operations/o4', targetName='o4')])class Operation(wtypes.Base): """An Operation resource represents an operation or action available on a target resource. This is for defining actions that may change the state of the resource they are related to. For example, the API already provides ways to register, start, and stop your application (POST an Assembly to register+start, and DELETE an Assembly to stop) but Operations provide a way to extend the system to add your own actions such as "pause" and "resume", or "scale_up" and "scale_down". It has the following representation: """ uri = common_types.Uri "Uri to the operation" name = wtypes.text "Name of the operation" type = wtypes.text "Operation type" description = wtypes.text "Description of the operation" documentation = common_types.Uri "Documentation uri for the operation" targetResource = common_types.Uri "Target resource uri to the operation" @classmethod def sample(cls): return cls(uri='http://localhost/v1/operations/resume', name='resume', description='A resume operation', operationLinks=[common_types.Link( href='http://localhost:9777/v1/operations/x2', targetName='x2')]) class OperationController(rest.RestController): """Manages operations on a single operation. """ def __init__(self, operation_id): pecan.request.context['operation_id'] = operation_id self._id = operation_id @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Operation, wtypes.text) def get(self): """Return this operation.""" error = _("Not implemented") pecan.response.translatable_error = error raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(unicode(error)) @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Operation, wtypes.text, body=Operation) def put(self, data): """Modify this operation.""" error = _("Not implemented") pecan.response.translatable_error = error raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(unicode(error)) @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(None, wtypes.text, status_code=204) def delete(self): """Delete this operation.""" error = _("Not implemented") pecan.response.translatable_error = error raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(unicode(error)) class Operations(wtypes.Base): """A collection of operations returned on listing. """ uri = common_types.Uri "Uri to the Operations" name = wtypes.text "Name of the operation" type = wtypes.text "Operation type" description = wtypes.text "Description of the operation" targetResource = common_types.Uri "Target resource uri to the operation" operationLinks = [common_types.Link] "List of links to the available operations" @classmethod def sample(cls): return cls(uri='http://localhost/v1/operations', operationLinks=[common_types.Link( href='http://localhost:9777/v1/operations/y4', targetName='y4')]) class OperationsController(rest.RestController): """Manages operations on the operations collection.""" @pecan.expose() def _lookup(self, operation_id, *remainder): if remainder and not remainder[-1]: remainder = remainder[:-1] return OperationController(operation_id), remainder @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Operation, body=Operation, status_code=201) def post(self, data): """Create a new operation.""" error = _("Not implemented") pecan.response.translatable_error = error raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(unicode(error)) @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Operations) def get_all(self): """Return all operations, based on the query provided.""" host_url = '/'.join([pecan.request.host_url, 'v1', 'operations']) return Operations(uri=host_url, type='operations', description='Collection of operations', operationLinks=[]) operations = OperationsController()

commit_message:
Enable 'validators' attribute for each field.

Previously they were available only at form-level. Field-level
validators could be used to validate against different regexps (with
YAQL 'test' function, which is also added in this commit) and show
different messages.

Closes-bug: #1250823
Change-Id: I7d4e1119f1ad8651abe0c7ff3f6fb56ff7d84694
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/67/57467/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import yaqlYAQL_FUNCTIONS = { 'test': lambda self, pattern: re.match(pattern(), self()) is not None, } def create_yaql_context(functions=YAQL_FUNCTIONS): context = yaql.create_context() for name, func in functions.iteritems(): context.register_function(func, name) return context def make_validator(field, form, key, validator_property): def validator_func(value): data = getattr(form, 'cleaned_data', {}) data[key] = value form.service.update_cleaned_data(form, data) if not validator_property['expr'].__get__(field): raise forms.ValidationError( _(validator_property.get('message', ''))) return validator_func class CustomPropertiesField(forms.Field): def __init__(self, form=None, key=None, *args, **kwargs): validators = [] for validator in kwargs.get('validators', []): if hasattr(validator, '__call__'): # e.g. 'regexpValidator' attr validators.append(validator) elif isinstance(validator, types.DictType): # or list of YAQL validators if form: validators.append( make_validator(self, form, key, validator)) kwargs['validators'] = validators super(CustomPropertiesField, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)

commit_message:
Isolate tests a bit more

This patch isolates mongodb tests and adds new `shortcut-methods` to
base clases in order to make it easier for subclasses to access conf
instances, override them or even hook them.

Change-Id: I8fe05bf383198244616499adb60480859f1ec7c6

subject: Check if flavors exist before creating them.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-21 01:52:44.000000000', 'files': ['lib/tempest'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/3b80bde8c7345a5e8c217b6c5c256c2f83aa7900', 'message': "Check if flavors exist before creating them.

* lib/tempest: When creating the m1.tiny and m1.nano flavors ensure that
they don't exist first. This is important for Grenade where code may be
run multiple times and should expect that some things preexist.

Change-Id: I1772d4334f39d612f8a187eb5311a1b2caee3953
"}]
commit_message:
Check if flavors exist before creating them.

* lib/tempest: When creating the m1.tiny and m1.nano flavors ensure that
they don't exist first. This is important for Grenade where code may be
run multiple times and should expect that some things preexist.

Change-Id: I1772d4334f39d612f8a187eb5311a1b2caee3953
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/84/57584/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local available_flavors available_flavors=$(nova flavor-list) if [[ ! ( $available_flavors =~ 'm1.nano' ) ]]; then nova flavor-create m1.nano 42 64 0 1 fi if [[ ! ( $available_flavors =~ 'm1.micro' ) ]]; then nova flavor-create m1.micro 84 128 0 1 fi
deleted_lines: nova flavor-create m1.nano 42 64 0 1 nova flavor-create m1.micro 84 128 0 1

Add Extensions to API

blueprint api

Change-Id: Iaf89c0e0188b8882a1c852ec5259aca7842df9b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/95/57095/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class Extension(wtypes.Base): """The Extension resource represents changes that the Provider has added onto a Platform in addition to the ones supplied by Solum by default. This may include additional protocol semantics, resource types, application lifecycle states, resource attributes, etc. Anything may be added, as long as it does not contradict the base functionality offered by Solum. """ uri = common_types.Uri "Uri to the extension" name = wtypes.text "Name of the extension" type = wtypes.text "Extension type" description = wtypes.text "Description of the extension" extensionLinks = [common_types.Link] "List of links to the available extensions" @classmethod def sample(cls): return cls(uri='http://localhost/v1/extensions/mysql', name='mysql', description='A mysql extension', extensionLinks=common_types.Link( href='http://localhost:9777/v1/extensions/x2', targetName='x2')) class ExtensionController(rest.RestController): """Manages operations on a single extension. """ def __init__(self, extension_id): pecan.request.context['extension_id'] = extension_id self._id = extension_id @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(Extension, wtypes.text) def get(self): """Return this extension.""" error = _("Not implemented") pecan.response.translatable_error = error raise wsme.exc.ClientSideError(unicode(error)) class ExtensionsController(rest.RestController): """Manages operations on the extensions collection.""" @pecan.expose() def _lookup(self, extension_id, *remainder): if remainder and not remainder[-1]: remainder = remainder[:-1] return ExtensionController(extension_id), remainder @wsme_pecan.wsexpose([Extension]) def get_all(self): """Return all extensions, based on the query provided.""" return [] extensions = ExtensionsController()

Revert snapshot "deploy_neutron_gre" 2. Run network verification """ self.env.revert_snapshot("deploy_neutron_gre") self.fuel_web.verify_network(self.fuel_web.get_last_created_cluster()) @test(depends_on=[deploy_neutron_gre_ha], groups=["deploy_neutron_gre_ha_verify_networks"]) @log_snapshot_on_error def deploy_neutron_gre_ha_verify_networks(self): """Verify network on cluster in HA mode with Neutron GRE Scenario: 1. commit_message:
Install Guide: fix heat endpoints

Use the same syntax as the other services for Heat endpoints creation in
keystone.

commit_message:
Refactoring of networking-related tests

Remove manually built dicts containing networking parameters and use fixtures instead.
We always made same changes to these dicts when fixtures were changed
so they simply diplicated networking parameters which are present in fixtures.

Change-Id: I426d813c764aabff044a073ab7c98d95295bec4c

commit_message:
Do not automatically re-enable the compute service.

Compute service won't be automatically re-enabled, in case it was
manually disabled by an administrator.

Closes-Bug: #1251520
Change-Id: I58ca0bbef664f5605bc83b9555348e4292a738ed

added_lines: def test_host_auto_reenable_failed(self): self.mox.UnsetStubs() service_mock_driver = MagicMock() service_mock_admin = MagicMock() # Previous status of the service: disabled: False service_mock_driver.__getitem__.return_value = False # Status of the service after admin disabled it: disabled: True service_mock_admin.disabled = True service_mock_admin.disabled_reason = 'Admin...' from nova.objects import service as service_obj self.mox.StubOutWithMock(service_obj.Service, 'get_by_compute_host') service_obj.Service.get_by_compute_host(self.ctxt, 'fake-mini').AndReturn(service_mock_driver) service_obj.Service.get_by_compute_host(self.ctxt, 'fake-mini').AndReturn(service_mock_admin) self.mox.ReplayAll() # Disable the host with exception self.connection.set_host_enabled('my_test_host', 'ERROR!') # Make sure the host is disabled self.assertTrue(service_mock_driver.disabled and service_mock_driver.disabled_reason == 'ERROR!') # Disable the host with exception self.connection.set_host_enabled('my_test_host', True) # Make sure the host is still disabled, since it was disabled by admin self.assertTrue(service_mock_admin.disabled and service_mock_admin.disabled_reason == 'Admin...')

commit_message:
Remove confusing message about mysql credentials

The Glance installation material contained a note indicating that if
connecting to MySQL fails the user should use the IP address of the
database server instead when specifying the credentials.

Besides being confusing in its wording this note referred to a situation
that the user could not possibly become aware of until starting the
Glance services later in the chapter.

Additionally no such warning is included elsewhere in the guide as its
presumed (via specification in the prerequisites up front) that the user
has set up their /etc/hosts files such that the controller host name will
resolve.

Change-Id: Ic5e6e1820628b0854effe7594b09610d030d0573
Closes-Bug: #1251458
backport:havana

Change-Id: Idbe4950bb3026e2201ddfddc4b58c2bf98972be9

commit_message:
enable Ironic password for keystone auth

The current version of the ironic-source.yaml uses AdminPassword, it
should use the ironic users password and not the admin user password.
The patch corrects an authentication error by adding IronicPassword
to ironic-source.yaml file.

Change-Id: Idbe4950bb3026e2201ddfddc4b58c2bf98972be9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/64/57564/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Parameters: IronicPassword: Type: String Description: Ironic password for keystone access NoEcho: true service-password: {Ref: IronicPassword}

commit_message:
Use upstream glance policy.json

We were using a local copy that was out of date and allowing all users
admin privileges, woops. Caught by tempest.

Change-Id: Ibf547bc763ace1298f506e5c95947b44bbce99bf

commit_message:
Timeout if seed fails to get IP address

Prevent boot-seed-vm from getting stuck in a loop if the seed VM fails
to get an IP, this was causing CI to run indefinitely.

Change-Id: Ib3f44e538186af8e090e1065b4b708b6ce95442e

added_lines: for i in {0..100} ; do [ -n "$VM_IP" ] && break [ -z "$VM_IP" ] && echo "$IMAGE_NAME VM didn't boot." && exit 1

commit_message:
Add ability to apply elements to current system.

This commit adds the ability to apply diskimage-builder style elements
to the current system, as opposed to a chroot.  The functionality is
implemented in new python modules under diskimage_builder.  A script
using this python code at bin/element-runner is also included.  There
are some simple test elements under diskimage_builder/tests/elements to
aid with testing/verification as well.

Change-Id: Ic2bcb8b9f17e03709048ee4702270ede9a95d064

Fix tox.ini to run tests in lockutils wrapper.

Without this line locks while parallel tests running won't be
working and there will be tests fails because of this.

commit_message:
Refresh request.user on session updates

Update the request.user Whenever the user related information
is updated in the session, to make sure they are always sync.

Change-Id: Ie803db0784971d1dc350527d9f43a1120759774f
Closes-bug: 1247186

commit_message:
Highlight use of 'file' Glance backend

Highlight the use of the 'file' Glance backend for storage and the
default location that images will be stored under this scheme. Also
provide some guidance on the amount of space this will require.

Change-Id: I412c938d5f2151b3f3f76d47542d25d67c1c9869
Closes-bug: #1239516
backport: havana
(cherry picked from commit eec6cdb7be32799e3a56fd5d7000d4c0435e7158)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/13/57613/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <important> <para> For simplicity this guide configures the Image Service to use the <literal>file</literal> backend. This means that images uploaded to the Image Service will be stored in a directory on the same system that hosts the service. By default this directory is <filename>/var/lib/glance/images/</filename>. </para> <para> Ensure that the system has sufficient space available under this directory to store virtual machine images and snapshots before proceeding. At an absolute minimum several gigabytes of space should be available for use by the Image Service in a proof of concept deployment. </para> </important>

commit_message:
Add swift roles to keystone

Tenants using swift will require these roles :
  swiftoperator - manage tenants, container and ACL's
  ResellerAdmin - create and delete accounts

Both are required by tempest tests.

Change-Id: I71f58964df74804f351a96ef079e53cdd17980a5

commit_message:
Handle COPY verb in account quota middleware

Since COPY verb allow to copy an existing object
we must check the size of the source object before
allowing the copy.

Fixes bug: #1201884

Change-Id: Ia37bc716be0c3e5a3174dc4370bb5084f81073ad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/70/51870/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_exceed_bytes_quota_copy_verb(self): headers = [('x-account-bytes-used', '500'), ('x-account-meta-quota-bytes', '1000'), ('content-length', '1000')] app = account_quotas.AccountQuotaMiddleware(FakeApp(headers)) cache = FakeCache(None) req = Request.blank('/v1/a/c2/o2', environ={'REQUEST_METHOD': 'COPY', 'swift.cache': cache}, headers={'Destination': '/c/o'}) res = req.get_response(app) self.assertEquals(res.status_int, 413) def test_not_exceed_bytes_quota_copy_verb(self): headers = [('x-account-bytes-used', '0'), ('x-account-meta-quota-bytes', '1000')] app = account_quotas.AccountQuotaMiddleware(FakeApp(headers)) cache = FakeCache(None) req = Request.blank('/v1/a/c2/o2', environ={'REQUEST_METHOD': 'COPY', 'swift.cache': cache}, headers={'Destination': '/c/o'}) res = req.get_response(app) self.assertEquals(res.status_int, 200) def test_exceed_bytes_quota_reseller_copy_verb(self): headers = [('x-account-bytes-used', '1000'), ('x-account-meta-quota-bytes', '0')] app = account_quotas.AccountQuotaMiddleware(FakeApp(headers)) cache = FakeCache(None) req = Request.blank('/v1/a/c2/o2', environ={'REQUEST_METHOD': 'COPY', 'swift.cache': cache, 'reseller_request': True}, headers={'x-copy-from': 'c/o'}) res = req.get_response(app) self.assertEquals(res.status_int, 200)

commit_message:
Proper update of objects

This patch fixes of updating rally.objects.{Task|Deployment} objects.
Now, objects have got a correct update of an encapsulated value of
internal representation of objects.

Change-Id: Iad775974c75bf28a83631753894eceafef06f6ab

commit_message:
Avoid returning stale token via auth_token property

The auth_ref token should take precedence over the user provided
token, since any call to authenticate() will update the auth_ref,
rendering the auth_token_from_user stale.

Change-Id: Ibc86dca840f4b8dd23856735616ee48a7b397fcd
Closes-Bug: #1244675
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/75/53875/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elif self.auth_token_from_user: return self.auth_token_from_user

commit_message:
Add performance metrics field to image locations DB model

Glance maintain a performance metrics dictionary for each image location
entry, it can be used to store different indicators.

blueprint: weight-based-storage-selection

Change-Id: Ife658ce2dd0097e71bcc778f5a1502f071775fb6
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import sqlalchemy from glance.db.sqlalchemy import models def upgrade(migrate_engine): meta = sqlalchemy.schema.MetaData() meta.bind = migrate_engine image_locations_table = sqlalchemy.Table('image_locations', meta, autoload=True) metrics = sqlalchemy.Column('metrics', models.JSONEncodedDict(), default={}) metrics.create(image_locations_table) def downgrade(migrate_engine): meta = sqlalchemy.schema.MetaData() meta.bind = migrate_engine image_locations_table = sqlalchemy.Table('image_locations', meta, autoload=True) image_locations_table.columns['metrics'].drop()

commit_message:
Fix heat endpoint in install guide

The previous endpoint description was plain wrong.

This patches to use the endpoint as described in:
https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/blob/master/files/keystone_data.sh

backport: havana

Change-Id: Ic90bace1e60f3cfddf00dd5594cee5d083b75ae7

Add pyudev to neutron requirement

ML2 plugin is required for neutron in icehouse, neutron-server needs
pyudev for binding, device and software management to enable ML2 plugin.

Fixes bug 1250311

commit_message:
Add verbose output to all stat commands

When you stat a container or object with the verbose flag the full path of the
reousrce will be displayed with the token similarlly to how an account stat
displays the auth url and token.

 * move some logic out of bin/swift.st_stat to test it
 * new module swiftclient.commnad_helpers for code you want to test
 * moved prt_bytes into swiftclient.utils to test it
 * fixed IndexError with prt_bytes on sizes >= 1024Y

Change-Id: Iaaa96e0308b08c554205b0055b8a04de581fefa4

added_lines: from itertools import chain def print_items(self, items, offset=14, skip_missing=False): lines = [] template = '%%%ds: %%s' % offset for k, v in items: if skip_missing and not v: continue lines.append((template % (k, v)).rstrip()) self.print_msg('\n'.join(lines)) def print_headers(self, headers, meta_prefix='', exclude_headers=None, offset=14): exclude_headers = exclude_headers or [] meta_headers = [] other_headers = [] template = '%%%ds: %%s' % offset for key, value in headers.items(): if key.startswith(meta_prefix): meta_key = 'Meta %s' % key[len(meta_prefix):].title() meta_headers.append(template % (meta_key, value)) elif key not in exclude_headers: other_headers.append(template % (key.title(), value)) self.print_msg('\n'.join(chain(meta_headers, other_headers)))

commit_message:
Use env variables as tripleo-cd cloud params

Currently, tripleo-cd element runs devtest-overcloud.sh script
passing all parameters used as positional arguments. Given the
fact that we already have 9 of them, it would be much more
readable and less error-prone to pass them using env variables
instead (additionally, this would allow us to use those params
in hand execute version of devtest guide).

This change must be approved only together with the corresponding
one to tripleo-incubator devtest-overcloud.sh script.

Change-Id: I68e4e659852c8549ad96fd7bf3f10957b652e648

Don't delete environment in case there are problems with RabbitMQ.

Environment should be deleted from muranoapi db only when conductor is
available via RabbitMQ.

commit_message:
Use separate stack-create overcloud call in docs

Currently, devtest_overcloud doc contains stack-create overcloud
call, which accepts parameters, that we don't expose to users in
devtest story (e.g. NeutronPublicInterfaceDefaultRoute). It would
be less confusing to users, if we passed only parameters, that
are defined in devtest doc and rely on defaults of the overcloud
template for the rest of parameters.

Change-Id: Iec097bee09ff06997fcfd7a4ec4a3d639ad6c77f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/45/57445/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix floating ips when devtest.sh is hand executed

When devtest.sh is hand executed, the public interface of the
network node in overcloud is not added to br-ex bridge, which
makes floating ips unusable. This is caused by the fact that
we don't set the name of the public interface in devtest guide
(it's in devtest.sh, but it's not put to generated html doc).

Closes-Bug: #1252304

Change-Id: I9035b5ab26498954b46051f1b9bb982f0bc07c86

Also fix issues found by pep8.

added_lines: # List of recognized (allowable) os profiling directives. "ubuntu"] # List of recognized (allowable) audience profiling directives. KNOWN_AUDIENCE_VALUES = ["enduser", "adminuser"]def verify_attribute_profiling(doc, attribute, known_values): """Check for elements with attribute profiling set that conflicts with the attribute profiling of nodes below them in the DOM tree. This picks up cases where content is accidentally ommitted via conflicting profiling. Checks known_values also for supported profiling values. """ path='//docbook:*[@%s]' % attribute for parent in doc.xpath(path, namespaces=ns): p_att_list = parent.attrib[attribute].split(';') for att in p_att_list: if att not in known_values: "'%s' is not a recognized %s profile on line %d." % (att, attribute, p_line)) cpath='.//docbook:*[@%s]' % attribute for child in parent.xpath(cpath, namespaces=ns): c_att_list = child.attrib[attribute].split(';') for att in c_att_list: if att not in p_att_list: "%s %s profiling (%s) conflicts with %s profiling of %s on line %d." % (p_tag[len_ns:], attribute, p_att_list, attribute, c_tag[len_ns:], c_line)) def verify_profiling(doc): """"Check profiling information""" verify_attribute_profiling(doc, "os", KNOWN_OS_VALUES) verify_attribute_profiling(doc, "audience", KNOWN_AUDIENCE_VALUES)
deleted_lines: # List of recognized (allowable) os profiling directives, note the enduser # and adminuser values currently used for the user guides. These should be # changed in the future to use the audience profiling directive. "ubuntu", "enduser", "adminuser"]def verify_profiling(doc): """Check for elements with os profiling set that conflicts with the os profiling of nodes below them in the DOM tree. This picks up cases where content is accidentally ommitted via conflicting profiling.""" for parent in doc.xpath('//docbook:*[@os]', namespaces=ns): p_os_list = parent.attrib['os'].split(';') for os in p_os_list: if os not in KNOWN_OS_VALUES: "'%s' is not a recognized os profile on line %d." % (os, p_line)) for child in parent.xpath('.//docbook:*[@os]', namespaces=ns): c_os_list = child.attrib['os'].split(';') for os in c_os_list: if os not in p_os_list: "%s os profiling (%s) conflicts with os profiling of %s on line %d." % (p_tag[len_ns:], p_os_list, c_tag[len_ns:], c_line))

added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -eu OK=/opt/stack/gearman-iptables.ok if [ -e $OK ] ; then exit 0 fi DISTRO=`lsb_release -si` || true if [[ "Fedora" = $DISTRO ]]; then # Check if the iptables service is active if systemctl is-active iptables.service ; then IPT_FILE=/etc/sysconfig/iptables if [ -f $IPT_FILE ]; then iptables-restore < $IPT_FILE fi # Gearman server iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 4730 -j ACCEPT iptables-save > $IPT_FILE fi fi touch $OK

commit_message:
Highlight use of 'file' Glance backend

Highlight the use of the 'file' Glance backend for storage and the
default location that images will be stored under this scheme. Also
provide some guidance on the amount of space this will require.

Change-Id: I412c938d5f2151b3f3f76d47542d25d67c1c9869
Closes-bug: #1239516
backport: havana
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/65/57565/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <important> <para> For simplicity this guide configures the Image Service to use the <literal>file</literal> backend. This means that images uploaded to the Image Service will be stored in a directory on the same system that hosts the service. By default this directory is <filename>/var/lib/glance/images/</filename>. </para> <para> Ensure that the system has sufficient space available under this directory to store virtual machine images and snapshots before proceeding. At an absolute minimum several gigabytes of space should be available for use by the Image Service in a proof of concept deployment. </para> </important>

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2011 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Local storage of variables using weak references""" import threading import weakref class WeakLocal(threading.local): def __getattribute__(self, attr): rval = super(WeakLocal, self).__getattribute__(attr) if rval: # NOTE(mikal): this bit is confusing. What is stored is a weak # reference, not the value itself. We therefore need to lookup # the weak reference and return the inner value here. rval = rval() return rval def __setattr__(self, attr, value): value = weakref.ref(value) return super(WeakLocal, self).__setattr__(attr, value) # NOTE(mikal): the name "store" should be deprecated in the future store = WeakLocal() # A "weak" store uses weak references and allows an object to fall out of scope # when it falls out of scope in the code that uses the thread local storage. A # "strong" store will hold a reference to the object so that it never falls out # of scope. weak_store = WeakLocal() strong_store = threading.local()

commit_message:
Use env variables as tripleo-cd cloud params

Currently, tripleo-cd element runs devtest-overcloud.sh script
passing all parameters used as positional arguments. Given the
fact that we already have 9 of them, it would be much more
readable and less error-prone to pass them using env variables
instead (additionally, this would allow us to use those params
in hand execute version of devtest guide).

Backwards compatibility is retained by accepting parameters both
as positional arguments and environment variables. Positional
arguments take precedence over environment variables.

Change-Id: Ieb3e9373c6f4364b8c83ac4ebe19268957c770c1

commit_message:
API accepts UUID for ports only

The MAC address may be changed, so it is not suitable to accept MAC
as filter for GET/PATCH/DELETE actions.

commit_message:
Fix the wrong db configuration variable in sample cinder.conf

Base on the cinder.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy.session, the db
related values should be in [database] group

Change-Id: I9f83b035232ff13a985c45d1e9c6be0e9cc6e2dc

commit_message:
Adds cinder-backup functional tests

Adds new tests to cover cinder backup api. These tests should
run against any of the cinder backup drivers.

Fixes: bug 1221335
Implements: blueprint add-volume-backup-tests
Change-Id: I2fe2b587f5b8880e004c31676b2ac4c7e69915e6

commit_message:
[REVERT AFTER RELEASE]  HA, Murano and Ceph  disabling

As HA, Murano and Ceph do not work in tech-preview-4.0 version,
we disable them on UI for this techpreview release (grey them out, not remove from UI)

Edited templates

Change-Id: Ib7a85996168b841b1ab51abe149f6416b99d620f
Closes-Bug: "1250373 "

not patched version of the classes.

For example if an import module gets a logger before monkey patching,

Change-Id: I7db37b6a6b15e0038c028bafd6c9f1f09f258955

commit_message:
Make the modules eventlet friendly as early as possible

eventlet monkey patch must happens before any reference can made to a
not patched version of the classes.

For example if an import module gets a logger before monkey patching,
it can made reference to not patched version of the modules.

The late patching can lead to bad performance, strange behavior or even to dead lock.

Now the monkey patch happens on module load, so it cannot be unit
tested as it was tested before.
The eventlet monkey patching happens even before the module's main function called.

Change-Id: I7db37b6a6b15e0038c028bafd6c9f1f09f258955

commit_message:
Removal of extra vim configuration comment

The #vim tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 has been removed
from the beginning lines of source files in oslo except for
/tests folder

Fixes bug : 1229324

commit_message:
Adds nova vif plugin for contrail/vrouter

OpenContrail System consists of two main components:
OpenContrail Controller and the OpenContrail vRouter.

- OpenContrail Controller is a logically centralized but physically distributed SDN controller
- OpenContrail vRouter is a forwarding plane (of a distributed router)
  that runs in the hypervisor of a virtualized server.
- This patch implements the nova vif driver for the vRouter.
- Corresponding neutron changes are at changeid
     I547426f1d4e0d1a305e179a785a5d517d058c381

Change-Id: Idef828f31b4d54f44f595c70aaea825cc2adf2cc
Implements: blueprint juniper-opencontrail-vrouter-nova-vif-driver
Closes-Bug: #1246837

commit_message:
Capabilities for any Cinder method to indicate special behavior.

For example some volume driver method can be marked as @stateless and
taskflow code will not change volume status upon calling this method.

Change-Id: If2f6ebc240c8b0fc5fa2bc37c5038a58b6cda831
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/03/54803/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # # Copyright (c) 2013 OpenStack Foundation # Copyright (c) 2013 Nexenta Systems, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Abstract capabilities interface.""" import functools CAPABILITIES_ATTRIBUTE_NAME = '_capabilities' class Capabilities(object): """Base capabilities class.""" def __init__(self, func): self._func = func self._func_name = func.__name__ self._capabilities = set() def __repr__(self): return "Capabilities for function %(name)s: %(capabilities)s" % { 'name': self._func_name, 'capabilities': ', '.join(self._capabilities) } def add_capability(self, capability): if isinstance(capability, basestring): self._capabilities.add(capability) else: for c in self._capabilities: self._capabilities.add(c) def get_capabilities(self): """Returns a set of method capabilities.""" return self._capabilities def is_supported(self, capability): """Checks if method support a given capability.""" return capability in self._capabilities def support_capability(*args): def wrapper(func): if not hasattr(func, CAPABILITIES_ATTRIBUTE_NAME): setattr(func, CAPABILITIES_ATTRIBUTE_NAME, Capabilities(func)) capabilities = getattr(func, CAPABILITIES_ATTRIBUTE_NAME) for arg in args: capabilities.add_capability(arg) @functools.wraps(func) def wrapped_f(*args, **kwargs): return func(*args, **kwargs) return wrapped_f return wrapper def is_supported(method, *args): """Check if method support required capabilities.""" if hasattr(method, CAPABILITIES_ATTRIBUTE_NAME): capabilities = getattr(method, CAPABILITIES_ATTRIBUTE_NAME) return all([capabilities.is_supported(arg) for arg in args]) return False

- test_show_interface_not_belong_to_server
- test_delete_interface_nonexistent_server

To improve code coverage, we should call Neutron API to retrieve
information of network and port, but it's not appropriate to call Neutron
API in Nova tests.

Change-Id: I1b5154b56d97f263c75c1eaa3768716d282ac854

commit_message:
add some negative tests for attach_interfaces

add some negative tests for Attach-interface API, and seperate negative
testcases into a dedicated file according to
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/tempest/HACKING.html#negative-tests

Change-Id: I1b5154b56d97f263c75c1eaa3768716d282ac854
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/31/49231/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from tempest import exceptions from tempest.common.utils.data_utils import rand_name from tempest.common.utils.data_utils import rand_int_id @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_list_interfaces_nonexistent_server(self): server_name = rand_name('test_attach_interface_') self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.list_interfaces, server_name) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_show_interface_nonexistent_server(self): resp, server = self.create_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) resp, ifs = self.client.list_interfaces(server['id']) resp, body = self.client.wait_for_interface_status( server['id'], ifs[0]['port_id'], 'ACTIVE') server_name = rand_name('test_attach_interface_') self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.show_interface, server_name, ifs[0]['port_id']) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_show_interface_nonexistent_ifs(self): resp, server = self.create_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) self.assertRaises(exceptions.ComputeFault, self.client.show_interface, server['id'], rand_int_id()) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_show_interface_not_belong_to_server(self): resp, server1 = self.create_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) resp, server2 = self.create_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) resp, ifs = self.client.list_interfaces(server2['id']) resp, body = self.client.wait_for_interface_status( server2['id'], ifs[0]['port_id'], 'ACTIVE') self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.show_interface, server1['id'], ifs[0]['port_id']) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_delete_interface_nonexistent_server(self): resp, server = self.create_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) resp, ifs = self.client.list_interfaces(server['id']) resp, body = self.client.wait_for_interface_status( server['id'], ifs[0]['port_id'], 'ACTIVE') server_name = rand_name('test_attach_interface_') self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.delete_interface, server_name, ifs[0]['port_id'])

subject: Fix unbound reference with multiple nics attached
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-07 01:33:02.000000000', 'files': ['nova/network/neutronv2/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/33adebfab40b550dd55f3496e935c4dc9411816a', 'message': 'Fix unbound reference with multiple nics attached

An unbound reference results in an undeleteable stack and in
some cases a general wedging of nova.  In the delete path,
an assumption was made that a port and net would have matching
network identifiers.  In the delete path this is not always
the case, such as when multiple nics are attached to a system.

Change-Id: I8c676f82bfa85c8b550b3ed14e55e60a41062e97
Closes-Bug: 1236116
Closes-Bug: 1235897
'}]
commit_message:
Fix unbound reference with multiple nics attached

An unbound reference results in an undeleteable stack and in
some cases a general wedging of nova.  In the delete path,
an assumption was made that a port and net would have matching
network identifiers.  In the delete path this is not always
the case, such as when multiple nics are attached to a system.

Change-Id: I8c676f82bfa85c8b550b3ed14e55e60a41062e97
Closes-Bug: 1236116
Closes-Bug: 1235897
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/76/49976/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # instance delete code path in nova will not pass a matching # port/network network_name = None if network_name is None: raise exception.NetworkNotFound(port['network_id']) try: network, ovs_interfaceid = self._nw_info_build_network(port, nw_info.append(network_model.VIF( id=port['id'], address=port['mac_address'], network=network, type=port.get('binding:vif_type'), ovs_interfaceid=ovs_interfaceid, devname=devname)) except exception.NetworkNotFound: pass
deleted_lines: # NOTE(danms): This loop can't fail to find a network since we # filtered ports to only the ones matching networks in our parent network, ovs_interfaceid = self._nw_info_build_network(port, nw_info.append(network_model.VIF( id=port['id'], address=port['mac_address'], network=network, type=port.get('binding:vif_type'), ovs_interfaceid=ovs_interfaceid, devname=devname))

commit_message:
Replace uuidutils.generate_uuid() with str(uuid.uuid4())

uuidutils.generate_uuid() is going to be removed from oslo,
so we need to remove its use in ceilometer.

This patch was use str(uuid.uuid4()) to replace
uuidutils.generate_uuid().

Change-Id: I311b65af33e36680cd801b07753a9b5f1a3e2b48
Closes-Bug: #1253497
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/98/57598/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuid return 'req-%s' % str(uuid.uuid4())
deleted_lines: from ceilometer.openstack.common import uuidutils return 'req-%s' % uuidutils.generate_uuid()

commit_message:
make record_metering_data concurrency safe

Recording metering might happen in parallel, and if two sqlalchemy
session try to create a source, a user, a project or a resource at the
same time, one of them fail with a IntegrityError.

This patch ensure the record_metering_data sqlalchemy session always
have the needed source, user, project and a resource by creating missing
obj in an other sqlalchemy session.

Fixes bug: #1237671

Change-Id: Ie8761ce1615c3142ad6ad2a400537f465f3bbf0a

deleted_lines: source = session.query(Source).get(data['source']) if not source: source = Source(id=data['source']) session.add(source)

commit_message:
Replace uuidutils.generate_uuid() with uuid.uuid4() in cinder

uuidutils.generate_uuid() is going to be removed from oslo, so we
need to remove its use in cinder.

This patch was use uuid.uuid4() to replace uuidutils.generate_uuid().

Change-Id: I8aaea61c1d5b15a22187ab9e4a6d6791f5244c37
Closes-Bug: #1253497
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/97/57597/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuid return 'req-%s' % str(uuid.uuid4())
deleted_lines: from cinder.openstack.common import uuidutils return 'req-%s' % uuidutils.generate_uuid()

commit_message:
Added some tests for os-update_readonly_flag

Added some tests for os-update_readonly_flag API.
There is not test for it.

Change-Id: I0ae4359d4a00fd93fb054aeb1fc4839feb5ac7ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/85/52885/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _is_true(self, val): # NOTE(jdg): Temporary conversion method to get cinder patch # merged. Then we'll make this strict again and #specifically check "true" or "false" if val in ['true', 'True', True]: return True else: return False @attr(type='gate') def test_volume_readonly_update(self): # Update a volume readonly is true readonly = True resp, body = self.client.update_volume_readonly(self.volume['id'], readonly) self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) # Get Volume information resp, fetched_volume = self.client.get_volume(self.volume['id']) bool_flag = self._is_true(fetched_volume['metadata']['readonly']) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) self.assertEqual(True, bool_flag) # Update a volume readonly is false readonly = False resp, body = self.client.update_volume_readonly(self.volume['id'], readonly) self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) # Get Volume information resp, fetched_volume = self.client.get_volume(self.volume['id']) bool_flag = self._is_true(fetched_volume['metadata']['readonly']) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) self.assertEqual(False, bool_flag)

commit_message:
Remove import uuid for some files

In some files, it import both uuid and uuidutils, but actually
uuidutils already include the main logic of uuid, so we can remove
"import uuid" from those files and use left "import uuidutils".

Implements part of bp no-import-uuid

Change-Id: Id71f1d4cc0de49c6b3c48135008ae1b704a9ca9b

subject: Ensure that the default instance sizes are nano and micro
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-11-21 02:39:38.000000000', 'files': ['upgrade-tempest'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/grenade/commit/bc1ec4ab6cca59d3e4b1617cc8d7a7614984761a', 'message': "Ensure that the default instance sizes are nano and micro

In order to let grenade run tempest tests in parallel on virtual
environments we need to create the same nano and micro guests that
we create in a normal devstack run. Otherwise we blow memory on
the environment, causing a scheduler fail, and sadness. Also no
cake.

We can't just remove the explicit setting of DEFAULT_INSTANCE_TYPE
as it then tries to recreate nano and micro flavors and fails. So
we hard code the the nano and micro flavor ids for the config file.

This is probably the wrong way to go about it, but just trying it
to see if this fixes the gate problem

Change-Id: I278fcc3f1ec3a2ea0ed27c7f0cddb683a5875115
Partial-bug: 1252170
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure that the default instance sizes are nano and micro

In order to let grenade run tempest tests in parallel on virtual
environments we need to create the same nano and micro guests that
we create in a normal devstack run. Otherwise we blow memory on
the environment, causing a scheduler fail, and sadness. Also no
cake.

We can't just remove the explicit setting of DEFAULT_INSTANCE_TYPE
as it then tries to recreate nano and micro flavors and fails. So
we hard code the the nano and micro flavor ids for the config file.

This is probably the wrong way to go about it, but just trying it
to see if this fixes the gate problem

Change-Id: I278fcc3f1ec3a2ea0ed27c7f0cddb683a5875115
Partial-bug: 1252170
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/87/57587/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Set swift timeouts higher

Devstack is commonly run in a small slow environment, so bump the
timeouts up.

node_timeout is how long between read operations a node takes to
respond to the proxy server
conn_timeout is all about how long it takes a connect() system call to
return

Change-Id: Ib437466a3fc9274b8aa49b19e4fe7fa26f553419
Co-Authored-By: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1252514

commit_message:
Fix i18N compliance with non-existant keypair

when test stack-create in Japanese language environment,
execute "heat stack-create" with non-existant keypair
"heat_key", UnicodeDecodeError will occur because
exception message has not been decoded correctly for
the following process:
(_("%(message)s") % ('message': ...)).

This patch uses safe_decode function in strutils module
to resolve the error.

Change-Id: I57cddae1b73a95cb9298daf51e49d5d7729467d9
Closes-Bug: #1249224
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/82/57182/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Enable polling minimization

In some cases the OVS agent might end up wiring a port for a VM
several seconds after the VM has booted. As a result, there is a
risk that the VM won't receive an IP address from DHCP in time.

This patch changes the default value for agent.minimize_polling to
True. This change should reduce the time needed for configuring
an interface on br-int consistently.

Change-Id: I009f606fd34a132376f1d50f8ccda9d35d064bfa
Related-bug: 1224001

Disable V3 tests

commit_message:
Add configurable ovsdb monitor respawn interval

If minimize_polling=True and the ovsdb-client process died, the
default respawn interval of 0 would mean that we'd start polling
again. This patch adds the option ovsdb_monitor_respawn_interval and
defaults it to 30 seconds.

Change-Id: I12c1e05ec4d6d2bd4d84024a91116e2ac3974868
Close-Bug: 1243867

commit_message:
Fixed concurrent PUT requests to accounts or containers

When concurrent PUT requests come in for an account or container, the
resulting DB access will try to lock the DB for writing. Normal access
will retry when it encounters a locked DB, change 0fdad0d9 introduced
a cursor for doing the initialization which did not have the retry
capability, resulting in a hard failure.

Fixes bug 1243973

Change-Id: I73b219e0f5eacf314d87b4d5e56c03daf51b2eca
